Phil --- The linked article in Nature makes it quite clear that an energy imbalance exists.

On the other hand, JoNova's piece is a typical denialist mismash.

There is ample actual observational evidence of the energy imbalance's effect on Terr's climate.

If you proceed to adjust exchange rates to account for trade imbalances in a dynamic-stochastic system (international trade) and use an equilibrium model to work out the prices,...then,...you are confounding "economic" imbalance with both random variations and systematic variations, not to mention effects of the natural frequencies of the system.

In effect, you will be chasing the rabbit.

If emperor, I would like to know what the system itself will do to periodic jiggering of the pricing before I put my imperial seal on the jiggering process. I really don't want to introduce disturbance into an unstable system if the disturbances are going to grow (unless my financial advisors can show me how to profit).

First, do no harm.

Spalding Craft --- There is ample actual observational evidence that an energy imbalance exists, i.e. global warming is in progress.

Tom:

I imagine the "LV" refers to Latvia and not Las Vegas. Interesting to be getting a response post from there.

My comment doesn't seek to absolve Jamie Dimon, or any of his fellow bank CEOs, from accountability -- SOMEONE needs to be held accountable, but I'd think Iksil would be reasonably jailed as part of that: Dimon didn't break laws, he merely wasn't sufficiently omniscient and ever-present in all the details of his far-flung operations to effectively control what happened; but Iksil certainly broke laws, as well as bank policy and risk management boundaries.

No, the comment argues that, while we must affix accountability, the notion that Dimon can be held responsible for that immense, kluged-up, utterly inappropriately complex mess we call JP Morgan simply is irrational and unworkable. If we don't do something about it, we'll never lack people to punish, and we can always extort $1.3 billion from deep-pocketed banks, but we'll do nothing to disincentivize aberrant and unlawful behavior, particularly if the guy who committed the acts skates. And it's the behavior that presents the systemic risk.

Break up the banks, and affix accountability at levels of concentration that make the level of accountability reasonably responsible for infractions that it should see and be capable of effectively controlling.

A lot of folks would agree with the sentiment "... better late than never". But the actions that directly precipitated the London Whale fine were committed by an individual, the JP Morgan trader Bruno Iksil, who cut a deal with regulators for immunity if he hung his management out to dry. One has to wonder what disincentivizes the behavior of future potential Iksils when they can do whatever they want, and get rich off of those actions, but on getting caught merely point fingers at others and get a free ride. Jamie Dimon may have been the individual most accountable before regulators, but he certainly wasn't the proximate cause of that problem.

As to that and the other regulatory actions, we should pause. When government comes after you with the obvious intent to make an example, and in this I particularly call to mind CFPB, then what option does one have but to pay the fine and say that you'll "do better" next time? After all, government these days can shut you down, not to mention jail you on a mere assertion of wrong-doing. What might have been the information, not one-sided as it now is, that might have emerged if JP Morgan had fought the fines in court? But, even at $1.3 billion, it's easier to pay it and let the whole thing die, so you can get back to business.

Break these guys up, to the point where a CEO really CAN be rationally held responsible for what a whale in London does, not merely accountable. And jail that whale.

Health insurers are easy targets, but they have not been increasing the costs of healthcare in the United States. Costs are driven up by the providers who charge fees a la carte for everything (to make a profit), and patients who demand the most healthcare, whether or not they need it.

Elisabeth Rosenthal's recent series in the NYtimes does not point to insurance company profits as the culprit for the unaffordable healthcare. Instead, we pay for things that are costly but not necessarily better for outcomes.

The next time you have a bill for a hospital visit before the insurance company negotiated rates are applied, remind yourself that it was not the insurance company that wanted to charge $15 for a single Tylenol pill.

San Mateo County's Skyline Blvd. is dangerous for cyclists. Too narrow, with motorcycles going 90 mph. Which gives me an idea how Ms. Covey's tragic death could bring about some good for area cyclists, honoring her life and her sport.

Skyline Blvd. runs along a ridge that has beautiful trails on all sides, but they're on state or regional preserves and the trails are largely off-limits to cyclists. Many road cyclists aren't interested in mountain biking, but even if they are, the restrictions discourage trail cycling and provide subtle pressure to stay on dangerous roads like Skyline Blvd.

Ms. Covey worked with the Natural Resources Defense Council. Most traditional environmental lobbies are either indifferent to mountain biking or hostile toward it, peculiar though it may seem. They bring pressure to keep trails closed to bikes, preferring for cyclists to contend with motorcycles, SUVs and pickup trucks. It is perhaps a gentle irony that Ms. Covey played key roles in the NRDC (which I assume is indifferent on mountain biking but AFAIK does nothing to encourage or support it) and died on a dangerous road when she could otherwise have been safely bicycling on the beautiful trails nearby.

As a tribute to Ms. Covey, perhaps the NRDC could work with local mountain bike groups to persuade the state and regional land agencies to relent and allow more mountain biking. That could save the life of someone else who would otherwise be imperiling herself on Skyline Blvd.

I quickly learned, while pbregnant, the range of contradictory advice out there. This was actually liberating...I decided that if Americans do X, Italians Y, and Chinese Z, and children thrive everywhere, then I could pretty much stick to my instincts. This took a lot of pressure off and allowed me to listen, smile, nod and move on.
For my more apprehensive and quite elderly in-laws, as a last resort I'd lie and say the pediatrician told me to do whatever it was they were worried about. Since they hold doctors in maddeningly high and unquestionable esteem, that always made them back down. On some issues there was no point in trying to explain my ideas..these are people who think an open window makes you sick.
On the flip side, I think many older and apprehensive grandparents in Italy appreciate and even envy today's moms...we are a lot more relaxed and free. My DH spent the first 8 months of his life in the house..a common Italian childrearing practice in the 1950s-60s!
The other realisation that helped me get by was to acknowledge that the grandparents would stick to their own practices if I left the baby with them That was a compromise I could live with, they felt more at ease, and in the long- run, a couple of hours every once and a while in which I wasn't totally in control really couldn't matter that much.
I get my best advice from moms with kids about 10-15 years older than ours...they have distance, but not too much, and usually a good comparative perspective.

I'm struck by how different the hospice approach to dying is from the way it was fifty years ago. I was a teenager when I lost both parents to cancer. They both died in the hospital; we could only visit during rigid visiting hours. The last afternoon I saw my mother she was barely conscious and I gave her water with a teaspoon; it was the only way she could take fluids. The next morning my Dad knocked on my bedroom door with the news that my mother had died.

Six months later Dad was in the hospital. The last night I saw him he was still conscious and lucid. He held my hand and said, "I don't think I am coming home." Then at the age of sixteen I didn't know what to say to this. We just held hands. The next day at school I was called to the office where they told me Dad had died and I was excused from school until after the funeral. That was it. It was 1968 and I was an orphan.

As painful as the death of a loved one is, I am sure the hospice process where families are allowed as much time together as they need, and pain medications are available to the patient, is much more humane than closing the dying off from the living.

Thank you for sharing your grief. I too would give anything for another five minutes with Mom and Dad.
